Functional space in a resident room does not include the floor area of:
Toilet rooms and bathing facilities;
Closets, wardrobes, bureaus, or lockers;
Entrance vestibules; or
The arc of any door, excluding closet doors, that opens into the room.
A room may not be used as a resident room if:
The only access to the room is through a bathroom or other resident room; or
In order to move from the room to a living room or dining room a person must first go outdoors.

For a program with a licensed capacity of 17 or more beds, a room may not be used as a resident room if in order to move from the room to a living room or dining room, an individual is required to first pass through a kitchen.

Resident rooms shall be for the private use of the assigned resident or residents. A resident's room shall have a latching door and may have a lock on the resident room side of the door at the licensee's option.
If a resident in a double occupancy room requests dividers, curtains, or screens between the beds to ensure privacy, the assisted living program shall furnish them.

A resident shall have access to a mirror either in the resident's room or in the resident's private bathroom, unless a physician documents in the resident's record that access to a mirror would be detrimental to the health of the resident.
A resident's room shall have window shades or their equivalent.
The assisted living program shall provide adequate closet or wardrobe space, conveniently located to allow each resident to keep personal clothing.
Furnishings. Unless a resident brings personal furnishings, or as otherwise specified in the resident agreement, the assisted living program shall provide the following to each resident:
A bed, which may not be a rollaway, cot, or folding bed, but shall:
Be at least 36 inches wide;
Be in good repair; and
Include:
A clean, comfortable mattress sized to fit the bed frame; and
At least two clean, comfortable pillows;
A bedside stand with a drawer;
A comfortable chair;
At least two dresser drawers in a chest of drawers;
A bedside or over-the-bed lamp; and
A sufficient supply of bath and bed linens.
A competent resident may waive the resident's right to one or all of the furnishings listed in §B of this regulation by signing a wavier and having the waiver placed in the resident's record.

The assisted living program shall inform a resident of all of the furnishings that the program provides. The resident may choose to provide a personal bed or other furnishings if they are not hazardous.
Toilets.
An assisted living program shall provide toilets in a separate room or compartment with latching hardware for privacy.
Buildings with one to eight occupants shall have a minimum ratio of one toilet to four occupants.
Buildings with nine or more occupants shall have a minimum ratio of one toilet to four occupants and a minimum of one toilet for each floor on which a resident room is located.
Hand Sinks.
Buildings with one to eight occupants shall have a minimum ratio of one hand sink to four occupants.
Buildings with nine or more occupants shall have a minimum ratio of one hand sink to four occupants and a minimum of one hand sink for each floor on which a resident room is located.
Bathtubs or Showers. An assisted living program shall:
Provide residents with bathtubs or showers that are enclosed in a separate room or compartment with latching hardware for privacy; and
Have a minimum ratio of one bathtub or shower to eight occupants.
Resident's Room.
An assisted living program shall ensure that a resident's room:
Is lighted by an outside window that:
Contains a glass surface; and
Has square footage at least equal to 10 percent of the room's required floor area;
Has a minimum of 60 wattage or the equivalent of artificial light provided for reading; and
Is provided with additional artificial light as required for other uses, such as night lights to enable residents to get to the bathroom at night.
An assisted living program shall provide additional lighting or wattage upon reasonable request by the resident or the resident's legal representative.

Common Use Areas. An assisted living program shall ensure that common use areas, such as entrances, hallways, inclines, ramps, cellars, attics, storerooms, kitchens, and laundries, have sufficient artificial lighting to prevent accidents and promote efficient service.
The assisted living program shall provide sufficient light to meet the resident's needs.
An assisted living program may not use space heaters unless approved by the State or local fire authorities.
Minimum Temperature. The facility shall have a system that provides in areas used by residents a minimum temperature of 70°F in cold weather and a maximum temperature of 80°F in hot weather.
Temperature Control.
An assisted living program with a licensed capacity of one to eight beds shall provide at least one thermostat per building.
An assisted living program with a licensed capacity of nine or more beds shall provide for each resident's room:
A thermostat; or
An approved mechanical device for modulating a room's temperature, such as adjustable vanes in a hot air vent.
An assisted living program shall:
Ensure that all rooms and areas have sufficient ventilation to prevent excessive heat, steam, condensation, smoke, and other noxious odors; and
Provide forced mechanical exhaust ventilation or an approved equivalent for:
All bathing compartments;
Toilet rooms;
Any area used for toileting;
Soiled utility rooms;
Designated smoking rooms; and
Other rooms, as determined by the Department.

If steam or hot water plumbing reaches a temperature in excess of 130°F or directly powered radiating surfaces are located in areas of the facility that are accessible to residents, the assisted living program shall position or shield the radiating surfaces in a manner to prevent resident contact.
The assisted living program shall ensure that the radiator shielding device:
Allows for efficient heat transfer;
Is constructed to minimize vermin harborage;
Is constructed of easily cleanable materials; and
Complies with all State and local fire codes.
An assisted living program shall furnish laundry service, either on-site or off-site.
An assisted living program shall ensure that the laundry is:
Adequate to meet the needs of the residents;
Processed and handled in a manner to prevent the spread of infection; and
Adequately sanitized by the use of sufficient hot water or appropriate chemical agents, or a combination of both.
Unless otherwise agreed by the program and the resident, dry cleaning services are not considered part of required laundry services in this chapter.
An assisted living program with a licensed capacity of one to eight beds shall provide:
At least one land line telephone for common use; and
A posting next to the telephone that contains the telephone numbers for the local police department, fire department, and relief personnel.

An assisted living program with a licensed capacity of nine to 16 beds shall provide at least one common-use telephone. If there are nine or more residents that do not have private telephones in their own rooms, the assisted living program shall provide a second common-use telephone.
An assisted living program with a licensed capacity of 17 or more beds shall provide:
Wiring in each resident's room that would allow a resident to use the resident's own private telephone; and
An adequate number of telephone lines and common-use telephones to accommodate those residents who do not have private telephones installed in their rooms.
If the Secretary determines that an assisted living program has violated this chapter, the Secretary, in addition to the sanctions set forth in this chapter may:
Restrict the number of residents the assisted living program may admit in accordance with Health-General Article, §19-328, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Require the assisted living program to reduce the number of residents in care;
Restrict the levels of care for which the assisted living program may provide services;
Require the licensee, and any of its staff, to receive remedial instruction in a specific area;
Require the assisted living program to use the services of a management firm approved by the Department;
Mandate staffing patterns which specify number of personnel, personnel qualifications, or both;
Require the establishment of an escrow account in accordance with Health-General Article, §19-362, Annotated Code of Maryland;
Direct the licensee to correct the violations in a specific manner or within a specified time frame, or both;
Notify, or require the assisted living program to notify, the representative or family of any resident who is affected by the noncompliance;
Increase the frequency of monitoring visits during a specified period of time; or
Enter into an agreement with the licensee establishing certain conditions for continued operation, including time limits for compliance.
If the Secretary determines that the licensee has violated a condition or requirement of an imposed sanction, the Secretary may suspend or revoke the license.
Appeals.

A licensee aggrieved by the imposition of a sanction under §A(1), (2), or (3) or B of this regulation may appeal the Secretary's action by filing a request for a hearing in accordance with Regulation .64 of this chapter.

A licensee aggrieved by the imposition of a sanction under §A(7) of this regulation may appeal the Secretary's action in accordance with Health-General Article, §§19-364 and 19-367, Annotated Code of Maryland.
This section does not, however, create an appeal for a decision made under Regulation .22I of this chapter.
The Secretary may impose a civil money penalty on a person if:
The person maintains or operates an unlicensed assisted living program;
A deficiency or an ongoing pattern of deficiencies exists in the assisted living program; or
The person falsely advertises a program in violation of Regulation .06B(2) of this chapter.
In determining whether a civil money penalty is to be imposed, the Secretary shall consider the following factors:
Nature, number, and seriousness of the deficiencies;
The extent to which the deficiency or deficiencies are part of an ongoing pattern during the preceding 24 months;
The degree of risk to the health, life, or safety of the residents of the program that is caused by the deficiency or deficiencies;
The efforts made by, and the ability of the program to correct, the deficiency or deficiencies; and
An assisted living program's prior history of compliance.
If the Department determines that a deficiency or an ongoing pattern of deficiencies exists, the Department shall notify the program of the deficiency or deficiencies and may:
Impose a per day civil money penalty until sustained compliance has been achieved;
Permit the program the opportunity to correct the deficiencies by a specific date; or
Impose a per instance civil money penalty for each instance of violation.

If the Department permits a program the opportunity to correct the deficiencies by a specific date, and the program fails to comply with this requirement, the Department may impose a per day civil money penalty for each day of violation until correction of the deficiency or deficiencies has been verified and sustained compliance has been maintained.
If the Department proposes to impose a civil money penalty, the Secretary shall issue an order which shall state the:
Deficiency or deficiencies on which the order is based;
Amount of civil money penalties to be imposed; and
Manner in which the amount of civil money penalties imposed was calculated.
An order issued pursuant to this regulation shall be void unless issued within 60 days of the inspection or reinspection at which the deficiency is identified.
A civil money penalty imposed on a person under this chapter may not exceed $10,000 for each offense.
In setting the amount of the civil money penalty under this chapter, the Secretary shall consider the following factors:
Nature, number, and seriousness of the deficiencies;
The degree of risk to the health, life, or safety of the residents of the program that is caused by the deficiency or deficiencies;
The efforts made by, and the ability of the program to correct, the deficiency or deficiencies;
Whether the amount of the civil money penalty will jeopardize the financial ability of the program to continue operation as a program; and
Other factors as justice may require.
A person aggrieved by the action of the Secretary under this regulation may appeal the Secretary's action by filing a request for a hearing in accordance with Regulation .64 of this chapter.
A hearing on the appeal shall be held consistent with the State Government Article, Title 10, Annotated Code of Maryland.
The Secretary shall have the burden of proof with respect to the imposition of the civil money penalties under this chapter.
Operating Without a License.
A person may not knowingly and willfully operate, maintain, or own an assisted living program without a license.
A person who violates §A(1) of this regulation is guilty of a felony and on conviction is subject to:
For a first offense, a fine not exceeding $10,000, imprisonment not exceeding 5 years, or both; and
For a subsequent offense, a fine not exceeding $20,000, imprisonment not exceeding 5 years, or both.

When the Department finds an assisted living program to be in violation of §A(1) of this regulation, the Department shall send written notice to the program 30 days before the State files charges under §A(1) of this regulation in order to give the program an opportunity to come into compliance with the licensure requirements.
A person may not be subject to §A(2) of this regulation if the person has:
Applied in good faith to the Department for an assisted living program license;
Is awaiting a decision from the Department regarding the application; and
Has not been denied an assisted living program license on a prior occasion.
In recommending the amount of civil money penalty under §A(2) of this regulation, the State shall consider factors including the:
Nature, number, and seriousness of the violations; and
Ability of the assisted living program to pay the penalty.

A person maintaining and operating an assisted living program which is in violation of this chapter is guilty of a felony, and, on conviction, shall be fined not more than $1,000. Each day that the assisted living program operates after the first conviction, without correction of the cited violation, is considered a subsequent offense and may subject the operator to further prosecution.
The Department shall establish a health care quality account in the Department for assisted living programs.
The health care quality account shall be funded by civil money penalties paid by assisted living programs.
The Department shall use funds from the health care quality account to improve the quality of care in assisted living programs.
Expenditure of funds may include, but is not limited to, the following:
Funding for the establishment and operation of a demonstration project;
A grant award;
Relocation of residents in crisis situations;
Provision of educational programs to assisted living programs, the Office of Health Care Quality, other government, professional, or advocacy agencies, and consumers; and
Any other purpose that will directly improve quality of care.
Suggestions for the use of funds may be submitted to the Department from:
Members of the public;
Advocacy organizations;
Government agencies;
Professional organizations including trade associations;
Assisted living programs; and
Assisted living associations.
Decision on Expenditure of Funds.
The Department, in its sole discretion, shall decide how to spend funds from the health care quality account.

The Department's decision to spend funds or not to spend funds for a specific project or purpose is not a contested case as defined in State Government Article, §10-202(d), Annotated Code of Maryland, and therefore may not be appealed.
The Secretary may immediately suspend a license on finding that the public health, safety, or welfare imperatively requires emergency action.
The Department shall deliver a written notice to the assisted living program:
Informing the program of the emergency suspension;
Giving the reasons for the action and the regulation or regulations with which the licensee has failed to comply that forms the basis for the emergency suspension; and
Notifying the assisted living program of its right to request a hearing and to be represented by counsel.
The filing of a hearing request does not stay the emergency action.
When a license is suspended by emergency action:
The assisted living program shall immediately return the license to the Department;
The assisted living program shall stop providing assisted living services immediately;

The assisted living manager or alternate manager shall notify the residents or representatives of the residents, or if applicable, the representative of the residents of the suspension and make every reasonable effort to assist them in making other assisted living arrangements; and
The assisted living manager or alternate manager shall immediately notify the local department of social services Adult Protective Services Program of the emergency action.
In the event of an emergency suspension, the Department may assist in the relocation of residents.
A person aggrieved by the action of the Secretary under this regulation may appeal the Secretary's action by filing a request for a hearing consistent with Regulation .64 of this chapter.
Show Cause Hearing.

In addition to the right to request a hearing consistent with Regulation .64 of this chapter, a person aggrieved by the action of the Secretary under this regulation shall be provided with the opportunity for a hearing to show cause why the Department should lift the summary suspension.

If requested in writing, the show cause hearing shall be held promptly within a reasonable time after the effective date of the order of summary suspension. The time limit for filing an appeal with the Office of Administrative Hearings to obtain an evidentiary hearing shall be followed by the filing of a request for a show cause hearing.
The show cause hearing shall be a nonevidentiary hearing to provide the parties with an opportunity for oral argument on the summary suspension.
The show cause hearing shall be conducted before the Secretary or a designee of the Secretary, who:
Shall determine procedural issues;
May impose reasonable time limits on each party's oral argument; and
Shall make rulings reasonably necessary to facilitate the effective and efficient operation of the show cause hearing.
At the conclusion of the show cause hearing, the Secretary or the Secretary's designee may:
Affirm the order of summary suspension;
Rescind the order of summary suspension;
Enter into a consent order; or
Enter into an interim order warranted by the circumstances of the case, including one providing for a stay of the summary suspension subject to certain conditions.

After the show cause hearing, if the Secretary or the Secretary's designee decides to continue the summary suspension, the person aggrieved by the decision may request an evidentiary hearing before the Office of Administrative Hearings consistent with Regulation .64 of this chapter.
Hearing.
The Office of Administrative Hearings shall conduct a hearing as provided in Regulation .64 of this chapter and issue a proposed decision within the time frames set forth in COMAR 28.02.01.
An aggrieved person may file exceptions pursuant to COMAR 10.01.03.
The Secretary shall make a final decision pursuant to COMAR 10.01.03.
If the Secretary's final decision does not uphold the emergency suspension, the assisted living program may resume operation.

The Secretary, for cause shown, may notify the assisted living program of the Secretary's decision to revoke the assisted living program's license. The revocation shall be stayed if a hearing is requested.
The Department shall notify the assisted living program in writing of the following:
The effective date of the revocation;
The reason for the revocation;
The regulations with which the licensee has failed to comply that form the basis for the revocation;
That the assisted living program is entitled to a hearing if requested, and to be represented by counsel;
That the assisted living program shall stop providing services on the effective date of the revocation if the assisted living program does not request a hearing;
That the revocation shall be stayed if a hearing is requested; and
That the assisted living program is required to surrender its license to the Department if the revocation is upheld.

The licensee shall notify the residents, or residents' representatives, and the local department of social services Adult Protective Services Program of any final revocation and make every reasonable effort to assist them in making other assisted living arrangements. The Department may assist in the relocation of residents.
A person aggrieved by the action of the Secretary under this regulation may appeal the Secretary's action by filing a request for a hearing in accordance with Regulation .64 of this chapter.

A request for a hearing shall be filed with the Office of Administrative Hearings, with a copy to the Office of Health Care Quality of the Department, not later than 30 days after receipt of notice of the Secretary's action. The request shall include a copy of the Secretary's action.
A hearing requested under this chapter shall be conducted in accordance with State Government Article, Title 10, Subtitle 2, Annotated Code of Maryland, and COMAR 10.01.03 and 28.02.01.
The burden of proof is as provided in COMAR 10.01.03.28.
Unless otherwise stated in this chapter, the Office of Administrative Hearings shall issue a proposed decision within the time frames set forth in COMAR 28.02.01.
The aggrieved person may file exceptions as provided in COMAR 10.01.03.35.
A final decision by the Secretary shall be issued in accordance with COMAR 10.01.03.35.
